newsitem.title: ISRAEL: No breakthrough yet to resume Israel-Syria talks.
newsitem.headline: No breakthrough yet to resume Israel-Syria talks.

text.p: Israel said on Friday that discussions between Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and U.S. President Bill Clinton achieved no breakthrough in efforts to resume peace talks with Syria.
"I think there is still no breakthrough between us and the Syrians," Israeli Cabinet Secretary Danny Naveh told Israel Radio in a telephone interview from Washington.

"We are seeking a formula that will bring renewal of the negotiations between Israel and Syria. The discussion between the prime minister and President Clinton dealt with that among other things yesterday but I cannot say that at this stage there is a breakthrough."
On Thursday, at a news conference with Netanyahu after their fourth meeting since the Israeli prime minister took office, Clinton said he was hopeful Israel and Syria would resume talks.
"I do feel encouraged by the discussions we've had that there are things worth working on, but I have nothing specific to say at this time," Clinton said.
Later, Netanyahu gave no indication he was prepared to soften his refusal to give up occupation of the Golan Heights which Israel captured from Syria in the 1967 Middle East war.

"No. We have a stated position," he told reporters at the Defence Department, where he met Defence Secretary William Cohen. "It is clear that we think the Golan Heights is crucial, vital territory for the defence of Israel. And that position has not changed."

Naveh said Netanyahu had brought a "creative" formula for re-starting the Syrian-Israeli talks suspended nearly a year ago after Palestinian militant suicide attacks killed 59 people in Israel. But Naveh declined to elaborate.

Asked if the next stage would be a U.S. envoy taking Israel's proposals to Damascus, Naveh said: "I don't think we've reached that stage. I think after the visit here, the American administration will be in contact also with the Syrians."
Syria says the previous Israeli government that was defeated in elections last May by Netanyahu's Likud party had agreed to return all of the Golan Heights.
But Netanyahu has rejected trading land for peace and insists that talks should resume without any conditions.
The previous government publicly said it was willing to make a partial pullback from the Golan.
